sections.content: This lesson introduces CRM Kiosk Studio at a high level. The class should be able to understand at the end of this lesson what a Kiosk is, what can be done with a Kiosk, and why a customer might choose to use a Kiosk over a Wizard or other form.
Give the class about 10/15 minutes to look over the KB for Kiosk studio. Ask the class to voice at least 3 use cases (collectively) for using a Kiosk.

Kiosk Studio is a button-guided interface. It mimics other types of short-form forms, typically in an embedded or pop-up interface somewhere in the CRM. It allows businesses to collect information from users who:

items: Should not have full CRM access
Only need to submit specific data
Need a simplified, guided interface

sections.content: "Collecting information" in this context doesn't necessarily mean information that will be applied to a record. Instead, inputs from the user can be used as search criteria for record lookup, email content, parameters in a custom function, as well as record creation.
Show a working, already built Kiosk to establish what the interface looks like, and how a user interfaces with a Kiosk.
You can show the same Kiosk being used in multiple places, like in a Dashboard, inside a record, etc to illustrate a Kiosk's versatility.
What Are Kiosks Used For, and Why Would You Use One?

items: Walk-in customer intake
Event registrations
Internal requests
Front-desk or public-facing data collection

sections.content: Kiosks allow you to present fields to a user for them to input data. The data can be single line, picklists, email fields, URL fields, etc. Later down the configuration chain, that information can either be used logically to show different interface pages, to create records, as parameters in a custom function or all three if that's the goal.
Why Use a Kiosk Instead of a CRM Form?

In addition to simplifying user interfaces, Kiosks offer far more flexibility than standard CRM forms. While CRM create pages are designed primarily for record creation or updates, kiosks are built to guide users through a process that may or may not result in record creation.

items: Perform quick, filtered lookups of existing records
Execute actions at multiple points within a single flow
Branch based on prior inputs or conditions
Perform tasks even when creating or editing a record is not the primary goal

sections.content: Creating a record is only one possible outcome of a kiosk. In many cases, the goal is to guide a user through a decision, gather information, or perform actions without exposing the full CRM interface. This can either be for security reasons, or for ease of use.

Standard CRM create pages can trigger automation, but this usually relies on workflow rules that run only when a record is saved or updated. Kiosks work differently. Their button-guided structure allows actions to occur at multiple stages of the interaction, without requiring a record to be created or edited immediately. If record creation is needed, the kiosk can still handle that as part of the process.
Kiosks are also designed with control and safety in mind:

items: Users only see the fields and options they need
Users do not have access to any CRM records or modules to use a Kiosk
Fewer mistakes occur because steps are guided
There is less risk of accidental record edits or deletions
Kiosk users do not require a CRM license if used within a Portal, allowing customers, vendors, or other third-party entities to interact with your system

sections.content: How Kiosks Relate to CRM Records

items: Kiosks can still create or update CRM records
Fields can map directly to CRM modules (but do not have to)
Validation rules, required fields, and automation still apply
Receptionist logging a new Lead
Event staff capturing Contacts
Employees submitting internal requests
Customers filling out intake forms

sections.content: While we've covered what Kiosks are, we haven't talked about what makes them different from other types of forms or interfaces in CRM.
Wizards and Create pages and Canvas forms in CRM are all intended to create a record by the end. The point is to input the field data that will be available on a record when the form is completed.

Kiosks can do the same, but that's only one of many actions you can perform with a kiosk. Kiosks have the added benefit of allowing you to create multiple records at once and even link them together all within the same interface.

Kiosks can also be embedded into records for the purpose of providing information, like simply showing other connected records at a glance, or providing an interface within a record to quickly schedule a meeting, like with a single button press.
Present one or two use-cases for a Kiosk. Two examples could be:

items: An embedded Kiosk for scheduling a meeting or task with one button press
A kiosk that lives on a dashboard and allows for quickly looking up a contact and creating a deal or meeting or other record for them

sections.content: Show a simple kiosk and how to add **Screens**, **GetRecords**, **Decisions**, and **Actions**.
Show the record created in CRM afterward.

**Key Takeaway:** Kiosks provide a flexible, button-guided interface that can perform lookups, create records, execute custom functions, and branch based on user input—all while maintaining security and simplicity for users without CRM licenses.
Overview of the new left-hand sidebar:

items: **Primary Sidebar:** Modules, Reports, Analytics, Requests, Marketplace, Global Search, Add New, Calendar, Mail Magnet, Signals, Setup, Profile
**Secondary Sidebar:** Context-sensitive options, Edit layouts, access folders, add webforms
Click through the primary sidebar options
Show how secondary sidebar changes contextually
Demonstrate finding a module, accessing calendar, navigating to Setup

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** Emphasize how the new vertical navigation saves space and is context-aware. Help reps build familiarity so they can walk customers through finding key items like Reports, Calendar, and Setup. Sidebar logic mimics other modern business tools.

items: Replaces traditional tab groups
A collection of modules specific to a department or team
Acts as the default CRM view
Contains all traditional modules unless changed by central admin
This happens when turning on CRM4E for existing accounts
The CRM Teamspace when starting a new subscription will be here as well with the traditional modules
**CRM Plus:** Teamspace users = Lite Users
**Zoho One:** Teamspace users = Teamspace Users
**Standalone CRM:** Also uses Teamspace Users

sections.content: Demo: Identifying and Navigating a Teamspace

items: Open the CRM and switch between Teamspaces using the dropdown
Show how modules and folders change depending on the active Teamspace
Compare CRM Teamspace to another custom Teamspace

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** Draw a comparison between Teamspaces and folders for modules by department. Teamspaces help segment visibility so users only see what's relevant to them. CRM Teamspace is the "legacy" CRM tab group. Point out this can still be used for broad visibility.

items: Who can create a Teamspace
Assigning the Teamspace Admin (only one allowed)
Adding/removing modules from the Teamspace
Reorganizing folders and adding modules to folders
Difference between Org modules and Team modules
Go to **Setup > Teamspaces**
Create a new Teamspace, name it, and assign an admin
Add modules and organize them into folders
Switch into that Teamspace to preview the view

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** One Teamspace Admin per space — make that distinction clear. Teamspaces give teams control without affecting CRM-wide settings.

items: Modules tied to one or more Teamspaces
Created for team-specific workflows
Start from scratch or use templates (HR, Finance, Legal, etc.)
Assigning Team Module Admins (can be multiple)
Customizing access down to field-level
Creating automations (blueprints, workflows, etc.)
Within a Teamspace, click **"Create Module"**
Select template and start from scratch
Start with a Template. Show the ability to customize what fields are here, and the lookup fields it generates automatically

Start from scratch and emphasize the need to put a lookup field for this module to "make sense" and be connected to existing modules (if the need for the new module is for augmenting existing modules/records)
Add fields, especially lookup fields for cross-module connections
Assign multiple admins to the module
Show field-level permissions screen

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** Team Modules are NOT the same as standard modules — they're scoped to Teamspaces. Emphasize field-level customization and how they allow for tailored user roles. Use templates when available, especially during early implementation.

items: Types of users: **Manager**, **Member**, **Participant**, **Requester**
Role assignment per Team Module (not global)
CRM Roles/Profiles still apply for general access
Navigate to a Team Module > Settings > Users & Permissions
Assign a user as Manager, Member, Participant
Show how a Requester can be added
Preview the access differences by impersonating users

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** Clarify that these roles apply per module — not globally. Expect questions like "Why can't I see another user's record?" → likely due to Participant/Member permissions. Role confusion is common, so this demo will help reps troubleshoot visibility issues.

items: External to the team
Can request new records in a module they don't have access to
Requests are visible only in the **"My Requests"** tab
Ideal for legal/review/support workflows

sections.content: Demo: Making a Request as a Requester

items: Navigate to the **"Requests"** icon in the sidebar
Submit a new request for a record in another Team Module
Switch to the Teamspace user and show how they view and complete that request

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** Highlight Requesters as a major innovation — limited access with the ability to interact. The requester DOES "own" the record, though they cannot see the actual module - only by proxy of the Requests module. Make the "Request a Quote" example relatable: perfect use case. Use the example that Zoho Sales might make use of this by creating a "Support" request. Reps may need to explain how Requesters can track progress through the Requests tab.

items: For the most part, the requests tab is like a list view for records in a module, but ONLY for your requests that you've submitted
There are no custom views in the Requests module
Requests module contains requests you've made for any module, so multiple module's requests are seen here
Global create-module permission
Teamspace Admin scope
Visibility determined by Teamspace membership
Show difference in UI between a user with and without module creation rights
Show that only Teamspace Admins see the **"Create Module"** button within that space

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** Reinforce that module creation requires global permission, but access is scoped to the user's assigned Teamspace. Maybe encourage reps to ask "Which Teamspace are you an admin of?" when permissions issues arise.

items: Recap of key concepts
Common support scenarios
Reference docs and internal escalation paths

sections.content: **Instructor Talking Points:** Reinforce the core benefits of CRM4E: modular access, team-specific workflows, and cleaner UI. Direct reps to reference material — including official Zoho articles — to build confidence. Invite questions, and share that more changes may roll out over time.
After completing this lesson, you should be able to:

items: Explain what CRM Kiosk Studio is and its purpose
Identify appropriate use cases for Kiosks
Understand the difference between Kiosks, Wizards, and standard CRM forms
Explain how Kiosks can be used without creating CRM records
Recognize the security and usability benefits of Kiosks
Understand how Kiosks can be embedded in dashboards or records
Describe how Kiosks allow users without CRM licenses to interact with the system
Identify the components of a Kiosk (Screens, GetRecords, Decisions, Actions)
Navigate the Next-Gen UI and understand the primary and secondary sidebars
Explain what Teamspaces are and how they replace traditional tab groups
Create and manage Teamspaces, including assigning Teamspace Admins
Understand the difference between Org modules and Team modules
Create Team Modules using templates or from scratch
Assign user roles within Team Modules (Manager, Member, Participant, Requester)
Explain how Requesters can interact with modules they don't have access to
Navigate the Requests module and understand cross-team collaboration
Understand permission scoping and Teamspace membership
